standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \blueD{87} \div \maroonD{17} &={}?\\\\ \text{So, } \maroonD{17}\times {}?&=\blueD{87} \end{align}$
Let's estimate first using friendly numbers.   $\maroonD{17}\times {?}=\blueD{87}$  is close to $20\times{?}=80$.
$\begin{align} 20 \times 4 &= 80\\\\ \text{So, } \maroonD{17}\times 4&\approx\blueD{87} \end{align}$  From our estimation, we know the quotient is about $4$.
So, let's multiply $4$ times $\maroonD{17}$ to see how close the product is to $\blueD{87}$.  $4 \times \maroonD{17} = {68}$

$4$ was just a bit too small. Let's try $5$:  $\greenE{5} \times \maroonD{17} = 85$  We only need $\goldE{2}$ more to equal $\blueD{87}$.  Since $\goldE{2}$ is less than $\maroonD{17}$, our quotient is $\greenE{5}$ and our remainder is $\goldE{2}$.
$\blueD{87} \div \maroonD{17}=\greenE{5}$ remainder $\goldE{2}$
$\begin{align} \blueD{90} \div \maroonD{12} &={}?\\\\ \text{So, } \maroonD{12}\times {}?&=\blueD{90} \end{align}$
Let's estimate first using friendly numbers.   $\maroonD{12}\times {?}=\blueD{90}$  is close to $10\times{?}=90$.
$\begin{align} 10 \times9 &= 90\\\\ \text{So, } \maroonD{12}\times 9&\approx\blueD{90} \end{align}$  From our estimation, we know the quotient is about $9$.
So, let's multiply $9$ times $\maroonD{12}$ to see how close the product is to $\blueD{90}$.  $9\times \maroonD{12} = {108}$
$9$ was too big. Let's try $8$:  ${8} \times \maroonD{12} = 96$

$8$ was just a bit too big. Let's try $7$:  $\greenE{7} \times \maroonD{12} = 84$  We only need $\goldE{6}$ more to equal $\blueD{90}$.  Since $\goldE{6}$ is less than $\maroonD{12}$, our quotient is $\greenE{7}$ and our remainder is $\goldE{6}$.
$\blueD{90} \div \maroonD{12}=\greenE{7}$ remainder $\goldE{6}$
